ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Very good overview of the history of revolutions, thoughts about political violence, nation-making, etc.

I developed an overall understanding of how revolutions are framed in a historical context as well as what aspects of a revolution are important in determining causes, effects, and relationships with other revolutions.
analysis of the radical enlightenment and the impact it had on the age of revolution.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I like Paris a lot. Great discussion leader, very funny, asks good prodding questions. Readings usually pretty good.
Weaknesses: Could've been helped by a little more grounding in Enlightenment thinking / general histories of some Revolutions (I.e. French) as these would become such recurring conversations that it seemed people had very different levels of experience to. Especially the Enlightenment stuff as the course often becomes as much a debate about the importance of Enlightenment thought / other ideology in the revolutions as it is a history of the Revolutions themselves.
The readings are excellent and the class discussion is very well-structured; I think the class is great as it is.

strengths: easy course structure, only two papers and participation
weaknesses: hard to feel prepared for the seminar. he poses no questions ahead of time about what from the readings we will be discussing. often, he will just pluck paragraphs and ask us to react, but these will be fairly dense political excerpts. The class favors people with a good background knowledge on the subject in this way. There are weeks that we hardly touch the readings, and other weeks where we basically needed to do a line by line analysis to have an real impact on discussion, which can be frustrating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend taking this course even if you aren't necessarily interested in revolutions or even history: I think the discussions are very engaging and benefit from having people from a range of different backgrounds.

Yes, but be warned that this is a political history course, with an emphasis on the politics. Traditional historical impact analysis is lacking. Much of it is trying to pinpoint the impact of certain "political thinkers" of the time on historical events, with little understanding of the actual historical events at play. The professor actively scoffs at looking at historical details at time.
